With increased resources from my bipartisan bill, more and more Mainers could benefit from the expertise of their local @MaineSBDC .

Samantha and Justin in Lewiston worked closely with their local @MaineSBDC to get their business off the ground. They told our office that without help from the SBDC, they “do not think that we would have been able to open or be as successful as we are.”

Want to make sure you get your tax refund on time? Make sure you file your return as early as possible, and file electronically if you can. 

You can find more info on how to e-file here: https://t.co/y8OsuzzcEa https://t.co/Ee6dkteIa8

Our 1st responders deserve these workplace protections. I led the initial effort at the State House to pass this law, which should be made permanent. I was grateful for the opportunity to offer testimony in support of this legislation before the Labor & Housing Committee. 

3/

This legislation in Augusta will help ensure first responders in Maine have access to the mental health resources they need, when they need them.  

2/
https://t.co/3oqxDoyDcI

First responders are there for us at our worst moments, often at great risk to themselves, and that can sometimes lead to PTSD. Early access to assistance programs, counseling, and treatment can make a big difference for firefighters, policemen, EMTs, and others.

1/

MSG Gary Gordon was an extraordinary American from Maine who gave his life in service to his country and his fellow soldiers. 

A Bath-built ship named in his memory would be a fitting tribute and an inspiration for our servicemembers. 

https://t.co/9BkKd6zU4g

I was honored to help revive an old tradition and kick off the @BatesCollege Winter Carnival last week by lighting the torch at the state house. Students ran this torch all the way back to campus in Lewiston! https://t.co/GaC6OeiL6D

Jim displayed tremendous strength over the past few years, forging ahead to serve his community despite his ongoing fight with cancer. I will miss working with him and my prayers are with Jim, his family, and all those who loved and knew him during this difficult time. 3/
We served together as leaders of the Underserved, Agricultural, and Rural Business Development Subcommittee of the House Small Business Committee.  2/
Congressman Jim Hagedorn was a strong advocate for Minnesota's First Congressional District, for rural America, and for our nation's small businesses.  1/

My team joined the ME @AirNatlGuard for a flight in the KC-46, a new refueler tanker that would help the Maineiacs self-deploy and develop other new capabilities. We’re working w/ the 101st Air Refueling Wing to ensure they’re in a strong position to compete for these KC-46s. https://t.co/pmmxFn4sME

It’s rare to find an issue that small businesses, labor groups, and the Chamber all support. But these 3 believe the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is a big win for Maine & America.

That’s important, and there’s lots of work ahead to make sure the law lives up to expectations. 7/

Mark Ouellette from @connctwithaxiom, a broadband service provider in Machias, talked about how the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law will not only create jobs and connect families to broadband in Washington County, but also make broadband more affordable for many households:

6/ https://t.co/sdLzBvay6g

One top takeaway on the economic impact: according to the @USChamber, the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is going to help us address the runaway inflation we’ve been experiencing for months now. 

Here’s how the Chamber's Ed Mortimer describes it:
4/ https://t.co/3G1tQHw05x

I often think about the impact of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law in terms of the Mainers building these infrastructure projects, their families, and the communities they’ll be built in. We can’t lose sight of the impact this law will have on the ground.

3/ https://t.co/nvO44Oysu1

This week, I held a @HouseSmallBiz subcommittee hearing to get more information on the impact the new law will have on small businesses, workers, and the economy.

2/

In addition to building roads, bridges, broadband, and more, the Bipartisan Infrastructure Bill we signed into law four months ago is going to create jobs, strengthen small businesses and workers, and, according to the @USChamber, help us fight inflation in the long term. 1/

Our casework team has helped hundreds of Mainers with tax and IRS issues. To help make this tax season a little easier for our constituents, our caseworkers put together a some tips for filers. 1/ https://t.co/2lD0Ss2QFq

I also stand in solidarity with the workers @MachinistsUnion Local 447, who are on strike for a fair contract. I support the skilled men & women of @steelworkers Local 9 in Skowhegan, who are standing together to bargain for a fair contract, including affordable healthcare premiums. They’ve worked hard to keep the mill running during COVID & they're key to @SappiNA’s success. @MEAFLCIO 1/

Our bill, the Small Business Development Centers Improvement Act of 2022, passed the House Small Business Committee earlier this months and would provide more resources for the SBDC program so that they can help more small business across the state.

2/

Last night, the House took bipartisan action to help address these challenges. 1/

In Congress, I’m working with Congressman Brian Fitzpatrick to pass the bipartisan Stop Foreign Funds in Elections Act to ban the practice nationwide. 

2/

Congress has access to info that the public doesn't. Lawmakers shouldn’t be trading stocks.

What can @MaineSBDC do for your small business? Hear it straight from the Mainers who’ve worked with them:

Our bipartisan bill will bring this program to more Mainers and help set their small businesses up to succeed.

.@HouseSmallBiz passed my bipartisan bill today to help expand the @MaineSBDC network. Small business owners across our district who've worked with SBDCs will tell you that the centers’ free business trainings, services, advising, and more were key to their business' success.

1/ https://t.co/aHceseIqLQ

@MaineSBDC's throughout our state help small business owners develop business plans, secure financing, plan their growth, and more. The sooner we get this bill passed, the sooner we can make these SBDC resources and expertise available to more Maine small business owners. 2/

This morning, I’m using my seat on the House Committee on Small Business to offer a bipartisan bill to expand the Small Business Development Center (SBDC) program in Maine and across the country.

You can tune in at 10am here: https://t.co/yz3VOsx8St 1/

That’s one reason I introduced a bill to expand and strengthen the SBDC network — including the 22 SBDCs located throughout Maine. Our bipartisan bill will bring this supporty to more Maine small businesses. 3/
https://t.co/tdhFhvASpV

Just about every small business owner I’ve talked to who’s worked with @MaineSBDC tells me their experience with their local SBDC was helpful. But not enough people in our state or across the country know that SBDCs are there to help them. 2/

From Fort Kent to Machias to South Paris, Small Business Development Centers, or SBDCs, are in communities across ME helping family businesses develop business plans, secure financing, and plan their growth — all at no cost to small businesses. 1/

Congrats to Leavitt High’s Mr. Davis! Isaiah & his students have done incredible things with Buzz Media, helping make 2 difficult school years a little brighter and more fun for students.

Looking forward to joining them for another show some time soon. 

https://t.co/7TVrgeA35Q

Thanks to @RepBrianFitz, @RepRashida, @RepMattGaetz, @repmarkpocan, @RepMalinowski, @RepSusanWild, @RepConorLamb, @RepKatiePorter, @RepJayapal, @RepChuyGarcia, @RepMGS, @RepSpanberger, @RepAngieCraig, @RepKathleenRice, @RepAndyLevin, @RepBillFoster, @RepOHalleran... 3/

Both @SpeakerPelosi & @GOPLeader have only recently expressed openness to this idea. Now, they need to put actions behind their words and allow a vote on a stock trading ban for members of Congress. 2/

https://t.co/qMNFP6ucp6

You should come to Congress to serve your country, not turn a quick buck. 

It’s past time to ban lawmakers from trading stocks and require them — at the very least — to place their holdings in a blind trust. It’s crazy that this position is outside the mainstream in Congress. 1/ https://t.co/qkX1Sk7FpJ
You can read more about the bill we passed today here: https://t.co/GFKQSDmqlo

It doesn’t have to be this way. Today, we passed the bipartisan EVEST Act, which auto-enrolls veterans in VA health care unless they opt out. I've been working to improve vets’ health care since I was a state rep and I’m proud to continue that work in Congress.
2/

Like many veterans, I spent a lot of time and jumped through a lot of hoops to sign up for and then actually use the VA health care I earned through service. More than half of Maine vets aren’t enrolled in VA care even though 1000s of those unenrolled vets are likely eligible. 1/

In addition to boosting funding for the program, our bipartisan bill specifically opens up more of the funding for rural police and sheriffs’ departments. I'll keep working w/ @RepTomRice, @RepSpanberger, @HerreraBeutler to get it passed. 3/

Congress must do more to support rural law enforcement. Last week, we introduced a bipartisan bill to triple funding for the COPS program, the #1 fed'l program that provides funding for local law enforcement to recruit & train officers. 2/

Read more here: https://t.co/ddOEfefcrB https://t.co/adFlxQr0DK

Too many rural communities in ME are experiencing a serious shortage of law enforcement officers. It hurts public safety, emergency response, and peace of mind across the state, and has contributed to some local PDs closing their doors in recent years. 1/

https://t.co/J5mKHmhU1K

Having served with Louie Luchini over four years in the State House, I can tell you first hand that Maine small businesses now have a professional and dedicated advocate at the SBA. No one works harder than Louie. 

https://t.co/4Tuht6SO9P

Bigger slaps on the wrist and more transparency aren't enough fix what's broken here. We should simply ban Congress from trading on the stock market.

More than 1 in 10 bridges in our state have potential structural problems, so this money can’t come soon enough.

Thanks to the Bipartisan Infrastructure Bill we got signed into law last year, $225 million in funding is coming to our state in the next five years to repair and replace crumbling bridges. 

By September of this year alone, $45 million dollars are expected to be put to work. https://t.co/Xq5cw7K1kg

Members of Congress have been abusing their positions of power to make $$$ in the stock market and the American people are right to be angry about it.

The Ban Conflicted Trading Act would forbid Congress from trading stocks. We should make it law. 

https://t.co/MYXMAgo7ZQ

This funding to clean up pollution at the Brooksville site is great news for the community. It's just the beginning of the good things coming to our state from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Bill we passed into law a couple months ago.

The first facility of its kind in North America will be right here in Maine. It will be great to see the Madison Mill humming with workers and forest products again next year.

It *should* be illegal for members of Congress to trade stocks. Period. We should pass the Ban Conflicted Trading Act and get that done.

Aging wastewater and sewage systems are some of the issues I hear most about from town officials, and I'm glad we're going to make progress on them. 2/

The committee found that my plan would: 
- Stop 100s of billions of taxpayer $$$ going to millionaires & the wealthy
- Save $250 billion in the BBB
- Protect the small number of truly middle class people who benefit from SALT

2/

NEW: The nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Budget analyzed my plan to fix SALT in Build Back Better.

“These new plans – and the Golden plan in particular – would limit unnecessary tax cuts for the rich & provide benefits to middle-class families.”
1/ #mepolitics https://t.co/0MexBEccOD

This bill creates a tax giveaway for millionaires that runs *5 years.*

But it expands the Child Tax Credit for the working middle class for just *1 year.*

Democrats need to take a step back & ask what it is we're doing here.

My op-ed in @washingtonpost: https://t.co/NvmveNTsbI

I’ve been warning about the need to deal with these looming Medicare cuts since March, and we’re running out of time to address the issue.

House leadership needs to stop putting this off and take action to help hospitals in ME keep their doors open & provide care to seniors. 2/ https://t.co/elAG2cccpb

Maine hospitals have had enough challenges thrown at them over the last two years. The last thing they need are cuts to the funding they get for providing care to seniors through Medicare, just because Congress can’t get its act together.

I visited Togus last month to celebrate Veterans Day and give my thanks to the doctors, nurses, administrators and other workers who help care for Maine veterans and their families. We’re lucky to have these dedicated public servants here in our state.
#mepolitics

.@SenSanders is right.

This week, I met with the senator to talk about addressing SALT and our shared belief that Dems have to choose between being the party of the working class or the millionaire class. We can’t be both. https://t.co/Wp0gdXEIaX

Great to sit down with Tom Saviello & business leaders in Wilton recently to discuss the importance of training in the trades and making more apprenticeship opportunities available locally. We need to make progress in these areas to keep young families and good jobs in rural ME. https://t.co/IQzxVOs9ZZ
.@SenatorBennet has it right. I sure didn’t come to Congress to cut taxes for rich people. https://t.co/Hfr7VS5fB9

Great to see my high school take home a state title earlier this month! Congrats to Hornets field hockey on a great season. 

https://t.co/WQH9uLJRvl

In just a few years, Springworks Farm in Lisbon has grown into a large, fully-fledged operation that supplies organic lettuce for Hannafords across New England.

It was great to visit and I look forward to working with them to find ways to continue expanding and hiring Mainers. https://t.co/l0OA4oL2gm
Wishing Mainers across the state a Happy Thanksgiving with friends and family.

We should be able to put money in the pockets of working families without stuffing cash in the pockets of millionaire campaign donors.

This shouldn't be a novel concept in the Democratic party. But here we are. #mepolitics

My op-ed in @bangordailynews: 
https://t.co/mACegjFc21

The single largest piece of this bill is a huge tax break for millionaires. There's no excuse for it.

I talked w/ @newscentermaine's @ChrisCostaTV about why I believe so strongly that this SALT tax giveaway has no place in Build Back Better. #mepolitics

https://t.co/IH8ATXUb07

.@GarrettHaake This isn't right. I objected — and continue to object — to the fact that the single largest part of this bill is a $275 billion tax giveaway to millionaires and the wealthy. Regardless of the net tax change, there’s no excuse for that provision being in this bill. https://t.co/32TJcsdpGz

Giving 100s of billions in tax breaks to the very wealthy should not be the tradeoff for lowering Rx drug costs, expanding Pre-K, and other programs for the working middle class.

We can fix this, but lawmakers have to take a stand and demand it. 

https://t.co/Qfrl6A43Lp

If folks don't want to hear it from me, maybe they'll listen to @SenSanders 

https://t.co/671AR1asOs

This version of the bill is not the best deal for my constituents. I’m going to keep pushing to make changes to the Build Back Better Act so that it lives up to its goals and delivers the best possible deal for the people I represent. 

6/
https://t.co/pwfiDdueWG

I want to keep working w/ senators to fix these issues. 

A billionaire tax could raise ~$557 billion.

For families in Maine, that could fund:
- More $ for LIHEAP heating assistance
- $$ to shore up Medicare Trust Fund 
- Capping seniors' out-of-pocket Rx drug costs faster

5/

I support many of the ideas in the Build Back Better Act: pre-K, lower-priced Rx drugs for seniors, expanded child tax credits, addressing climate change, and more.

But voting for these should not be contingent on voting for tax giveaways to millionaires.

4/

The current House version of SALT gives millionaires thousands in cash, while people who make less than ~$100,000/year get less than $20 on avg. 

This policy costs $286 billion. 

Why would we do that? I support @SenSanders’ efforts to mitigate these giveaways. 

3/

To start: tax billionaires and stop tax giveaways to millionaires. 

Many billionaires pay $0.00 in income taxes. Why wouldn't we tax them? @RonWyden has a good proposal that has been considered for this bill. 

2/
https://t.co/OpE8DEbIlK

This version of the Build Back Better Act is not the best deal for my constituents.

When the bill returns to the House, here are some of the changes for working people that could get me to a yes vote:

1/

Proponents have been saying that the BBB taxes the rich. But the more we learn about the SALT provisions, the more it looks like another giant tax break for millionaires.

The fact that more people and orgs on the Democratic side aren’t up in arms about this is wild.

2/

If you’d told me a year ago that the second-biggest piece of a signature bill of this Congress was *$280 billion in tax giveaways to millionaires,* I’d have told you the Republicans were in charge.

https://t.co/S6LHKNl3tm

1/

I led a group of New England lawmakers to call on @POTUS to tap into federal heating oil and gas reserves and limit natural gas exports. This would help increase oil & gas supply and start to drive down prices.

The president can and should take these actions immediately.

2/ https://t.co/F2XfqdP1hD

Prices for heating oil and gas are going up fast, which could mean steep heating bills for Maine families this winter. Many Mainers will need to see action from elected officials if they are going to be able to affordably heat their homes this winter.

1/
Our legislation has now earned the support of the FEC Chair @ShanaMBroussard. Let’s get it passed. https://t.co/vo2NLYrfP7

But last week, the @FEC ruled that current law allows foreign money in U.S. ballot question campaigns. 

The next day, I helped introduce bipartisan legislation with @RepBrianFitz to close this loophole and help get foreign money out of our elections.

https://t.co/STe5zBHRQ8

2/

American elections — from ballot questions to the presidency — should be decided by Americans, not foreign citizens or corporations. 

It’s illegal for candidates to accept foreign campaign money and we shouldn't let foreign money pour into ballot question campaigns either. 

1/

Not long after Veterans Day, Congress has a chance to deliver something meaningful for our veterans. Vets, their families, and Americans of all stripes need a memorial to post-9/11 veterans on America’s National Mall.

https://t.co/NNLr54Beh8

We see examples of Mainers supporting our veterans every day, but we all know there is more that each of us can do. Let’s take this opportunity to recommit ourselves and our communities to serving Maine veterans as they’ve served us. 

Happy Veterans Day. 

2/

I’d like to say thank you, from me and my family, to all my fellow veterans in our state. You’ve dedicated years of your lives, moved far from home, and often put your own lives at risk. That’s true sacrifice, and we’re a stronger country for it. 

1/ https://t.co/OFfvFOmAsF

I applaud ME Lobstering Union for filing & prevailing in the suit. It’s a great example of the power of unions to get results for working people.

This struggle isn't over and I'll be working with lobstermen to keep up the fight for fair regulations based on data & evidence. 3/

The judge’s decision acts on arguments that lobstermen have made for years: there's not hard data to suggest that ME lobster gear is killing right whales. Implementing this closure would cause serious economic damage to lobstering communities w/o demonstrated impact on whales. 2/

This decision is a victory for Maine lobstermen. For the first time, the concerns of lobstermen were weighed fairly and as a result we have a ruling grounded in common sense and the public good. 

https://t.co/kL4irT668w

1/
Read more here: https://t.co/O6XmAeeI6E 5/

I urged committee chairmen today to either:
- Address the problems with the Medicare dental proposal
OR
- Remove this potentially harmful half-measure from the bill

Medicare is too important to risk the program's integrity by adding underdeveloped, half-baked provisions.

4/ https://t.co/Ek6oHigWB8

Waiting 7-10 years to phase in Medicare dental coverage, as the bill currently does, is a gimmick to make the program look cheaper on paper. For too many seniors, it would amount to another empty promise.

3/

I support expanding Medicare to cover dental care. But the way the bill is written, no senior would get Medicare dental coverage until 2028, and the full benefits wouldn’t be available for over a decade. 

2/

Last week, I laid out some of the problems I see with the draft reconciliation bill proposal and the hard choices that I believe need to be made in the legislation. 

One of the most important issues is the expansion of Medicare benefits.

1/ https://t.co/da99jNFGh2

This is great news for small businesses and families across our border communities in Maine. 

My colleagues and I in the Maine delegation have been pushing for changes like this for months now and I'm glad to see the administration finally take action. https://t.co/9jlQnFxJBB

The Maine Lobstering Union is 100% right to take this action and I hope they're successful. We can't leave any stone unturned to find ways to mitigate these unsupported, over-reaching regulations.
